persona.name: Federico Treviño Sada

occupation.title: Senior IT Consultant / Engagement Manager
occupation.organization: Regional technology consultancy (mid-sized firm providing digital transformation to manufacturing and professional services clients)
occupation.description: Federico leads client engagements that help established companies in the northern industrial corridor modernize IT operations, migrate workloads to cloud platforms, and implement ERP/PLM integrations. His role mixes technical leadership, project management, and business development. Responsibilities include scoping projects, designing cloud architectures, coordinating multidisciplinary teams (developers, network engineers, change management consultants), presenting ROI cases to C-level executives, negotiating contracts, and ensuring projects meet quality and security standards. He is regularly involved in mentoring junior consultants, preparing proposals, and maintaining client relationships after delivery (support and upsell). He travels regionally for client workshops. Key skills for the role: cloud architecture, requirements capture, stakeholder management, budgeting and P&L awareness, fluent bilingual presentations (Spanish/English), vendor selection, and regulatory compliance for data and payroll systems. Typical challenges: convincing conservative manufacturing clients to invest in digitization, aligning IT scope with constrained capex cycles, and recruiting skilled engineers locally.

persona.education: Bachelor's in Systems Engineering (Tecnológico de Monterrey, Class of 2006); Master's in Business Administration with emphasis in Technology Management (ITESM, 2012). Thesis on adoption of cloud platforms by manufacturing SMEs. Additional certifications: AWS Certified Solutions Architect – Professional, PMP (Project Management Professional), CPD courses in corporate finance and data protection (CONACYT-affiliated programs). Attended executive short programs at IPADE (leadership) and a summer course in product management at Stanford Continuing Studies.
long_term_goals: Build and scale a regional technology consultancy that helps manufacturing firms in Nuevo León modernize operations and export services.
Achieve financial independence to reduce active work hours by his late 50s—invest in real estate and passive income streams.
Ensure his children receive international-caliber education (bilingual schools and university abroad if they choose).
Leave a respected family and community legacy in Monterrey: sponsor scholarships, sit on a municipal business advisory board, and be seen as a practical civic leader.
Continue learning (languages, management frameworks) and be fit enough to enjoy retirement travel with his spouse.
Own and maintain a second home in a coastal destination for family holidays (long-term property investment).
persona.style: Polished, measured, and businesslike. Speaks Spanish as his primary language with the Monterrey (Regiomontano) accent—clear consonants, occasional upward inflection when emphasizing a point. Uses formal register with older or senior interlocutors (usted) and comfortably switches to informal (tú) with colleagues and friends. Often peppers conversations with technical terms in English ("cloud", "deployment", "backlog") and business jargon ("ROI", "cashflow", "stakeholders"). Communicates with calm authority: hands used sparingly to illustrate points (index and thumb pinches to show scale), maintains steady eye contact, and smiles easily when hearing personal anecdotes. In writing he prefers structured emails with bullet points, clear next steps, and short subject lines. He dresses business casual: nice shirts, blazers when meeting clients, jeans or chinos on Fridays and weekends; favors neutral colors and one or two quality accessories (a discreet watch, a leather briefcase). In informal settings he can be warm and teasing with family and long-time friends, but with new contacts he is reserved until rapport is built. He uses humor sparingly—dry, observational—and dislikes loud or gratuitous displays of emotion in professional contexts. Uses WhatsApp for daily coordination, LinkedIn for professional communication, and Twitter/X selectively to follow business and news.

big_five.extraversion: Moderate. Comfortable leading meetings and social events, but requires quiet time to recharge; enjoys small-group socializing more than large parties.
big_five.agreeableness: Medium-high. Generally cooperative, polite, and helpful, but can be firm when business principles are at stake.
big_five.neuroticism: Low-to-moderate. Handles stress through planning and exercise, but can ruminate about work failures or missed opportunities on occasion.

Entrepreneurship should be encouraged with access to credit and mentorship.

Technology adoption must be measured, with pilots and demonstrable ROI before large-scale rollouts.
Property rights and legal certainty are central to investment decisions.
Security is a priority—effective policing and judicial processes are necessary for economic activity.

Children should learn good manners, respect, and responsibility early on.
Work-life balance is important, but professional dedication and reliable performance are expected.
Large handouts without accountability produce dependency; social programs should include training, evaluation, and measurement.
Labor rules should protect workers but also allow firms flexibility to stay competitive.

Local governments should invest in urban maintenance (streets, parks) to improve quality of life and business attractiveness.
Professional associations (chambers, guilds) have a role in upskilling and connecting the private sector.
He believes in personal responsibility for health—exercise and diet reduce systemic burdens.
Public schools need better funding and management but private options complement public services.
Political parties should be judged by competence and results rather than slogans.
Foreign partnerships and knowledge transfer accelerate local innovation when structured fairly.
He respects Catholic cultural values (family, holidays) but supports secular governance and religious freedom.

other_facts: Grew up in a multi-generational, white/European-descended family in Monterrey with a tradition of small-to-medium enterprise ownership; childhood surrounded by family business conversations at the dinner table.
Childhood hobby: building RC cars and disassembling household electronics to understand how things worked.
First computer was a donated desktop in high school; taught himself basic programming and pursued Systems Engineering because it combined mechanics and business logic.
Undergrad internship at a local manufacturing plant where he saw outdated IT systems and conceived his first small consultancy project fixing a payroll system.
Married Mariana after a five-year relationship; wedding was a family-focused event with both sets of parents deeply involved in planning.
Bought his first house with a bank mortgage in his late 20s; he refinanced it twice and now owns the family home with equity used for a small property investment.
Has one rental condominium near downtown Monterrey which he purchased as a long-term investment and rents to a young professional couple.
Traveled to the United States regularly for business and occasional family trips—comfortable navigating cross-border logistics and bilingual interactions.
